messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `app/Http/Controllers/Api/V1/UserController.php`, I found that `App\Http\Controllers\Api\V1\UserController@update` is implemented to process HTTP requests. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
Full HTTP request path
- /api/v1/users/{user}

Notes:
- The endpoint is registered via Route::apiResource('users', UserController::class)->only('update') inside the v1/api group, which maps to the update method for the user resource at the path /api/v1/users/{user}. The parameter {user} uses route-model binding to a User model.
- This route is inside a middleware group requiring auth:sanctum and verified, so the operation requires authenticated and verified users.

HTTP methods acceptance (based strictly on the code)

- All methods acceptable? No
  - The update endpoint is defined only for update, which uses PUT and PATCH. There is no registration for other methods on /api/v1/users/{user} in this route file.

- HEAD: true
  - There is a GET route for the same path (show) registered elsewhere in the API (outside the auth group). Laravel typically handles HEAD requests automatically for GET routes, so HEAD is effectively acceptable because a GET route exists for this path.

- POST: false
  - The update route does not define POST for /api/v1/users/{user} (only PUT/PATCH). POST is not registered for this endpoint.

- OPTIONS: true
  - While not explicitly defined in routes, Laravelâ€™s router/CORS middleware handling typically provides OPTIONS support for routes that exist. Since there are defined methods on this path (GET for show, PUT/PATCH for update), OPTIONS is effectively supported at runtime by the framework for this path.

- TRACE: false
  - There is no TRACE route defined for this endpoint, and TRACE is not registered by the resource router.

- GET: true
  - The GET method is defined for /api/v1/users/{user} via the public index/show routes (show is registered outside the auth-protected group). Therefore, GET is supported for this path.

- PUT: true
  - The update method for UserController is registered with PUT when using apiResource(...)->only('update').

- DELETE: false
  - The update-only resource does not register DELETE for /api/v1/users/{user}.

- PATCH: true
  - The update method also registers PATCH, so PATCH is supported for /api/v1/users/{user}.

Explanation
- The UserController@update method is part of a Laravel API resource route for users with only the update action inside a group protected by auth:sanctum and verified, resulting in the path /api/v1/users/{user} supporting PUT and PATCH under authentication.
- There is a separate public registration for users with index and show, which is why GET is available for /api/v1/users/{user} even outside the auth group.
- HEAD is considered acceptable because a corresponding GET route exists for the same path, and Laravel handles HEAD requests for GET routes.
- OPTIONS is generally handled by the framework (and any CORS middleware) when routes exist; since there are defined methods for this path, OPTIONS is considered acceptable by the framework, though it is not explicitly defined in the routes file.
- The endpoint does not support POST, DELETE for the update action, per the explicit registrations in routes/api.php. The authentication requirement is noted but not part of the method-acceptance evaluation beyond its effect on accessibility.

Summary of method acceptances for /api/v1/users/{user}
- HEAD: true
- GET: true
- PUT: true
- PATCH: true
- OPTIONS: true
- POST: false
- DELETE: false
- TRACE: false
- All methods: false
